linkTarget.anchoringText: The petroliferous Barmer Rift Basin is a narrow NNW-SSE graben structure as shown in Figure 01, extending towards north of the prolific Cambay Basin. The northern part of the basin has thick high quality fluvial sandstone reservoirs in the Fatehgarh Formation that overlies the pre-rift basement of Lower Cretaceous. The gross thickness of the Fatehgarh Formation increases in the footwall portions from south to north in the Down-to-the-West (DTTW) fault system. A similar thickness trend is observed in the un-conformably overlying Palaeocene-Eocene Barmer Hill Formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 01
image-wrap.caption: Elevation Map of Barmer Hill Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Elevation Map of Barmer Hill Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Barmer Hill Formation is divided into different members/units as shown in open hole log tracks in Figure 02, based on lithological characteristics (Chowdhury et. al., 2011). In many areas, the formation contains high total organic carbon throughout, with particularly significant organic rich intervals near the base. In the lake settings, particularly in northern part of the basin, upper Barmer Hill is comprised mainly of laminated porcellanite. This unit is 50-250 meters thick and is known to be hydrocarbon bearing within structural closures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 02
image-wrap.caption: Open Hole Log tracks against all Barmer Hill Units

formatted-caption.caption-text: Open Hole Log tracks against all Barmer Hill Units

linkTarget.anchoringText: The laminations in the upper unit consist of diagenetic micro-quartz, silt-sized quartz grains with high porosity (25-35%) and moderate permeability (0.1-4mD), organic rich and minor aluminosilicate clay. Figure 03 shows that these laminations are very pronounced at every resolution formed as a result of hemipelagic sedimentation within lacustrine environment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 03
image-wrap.caption: Core photograph shows Laminated Porcellanite of Barmer Hill (microcrystalline silica)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core photograph shows Laminated Porcellanite of Barmer Hill (microcrystalline silica)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Multiple zones of formation breakout were observed from image logs in vertical wells (Guha et. al., 2013, Chowdhury et.al, 2011). The directions of the main boundary faults in the Mangala field are generally coincident with the SHmax. No shear anisotropy is observed from sonic logs as seen in Figure 04 but the magnitudes of minimum and maximum horizontal stress differ based upon measured Shmin and estimated Shmax.

image-wrap.label: Figure 04
image-wrap.caption: No shear anisotropy is seen from sonic logs as slow & fast shear overlap

formatted-caption.caption-text: No shear anisotropy is seen from sonic logs as slow & fast shear overlap

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 05 (A) & (B) shows the main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on two stages of a vertical well depicting the results of the microseismic interpretation & fracture treatement pressure response. Figure 05 (A) in particular helps understand that the fracture length resulting from the two fracture treatment are almost similar causing the overlap of green & purple events from the top (length & width view) & also shows the fracture height.

image-wrap.label: Figure 05
image-wrap.caption: (a) Main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on two stages of a vertical well i.e BH-08 in Purple & BH-10in Green.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on two stages of a vertical well i.e BH-08 in Purple & BH-10in Green.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on two stages of a vertical well i.e BH-08 in Purple & BH-10in Green
Fracture treatement surface pressure response in BH-08 (on left) & BH-10

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 05 (A) & (B) shows the main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on two stages of a vertical well depicting the results of the microseismic interpretation & fracture treatement pressure response. Figure 05 (A) in particular helps understand that the fracture length resulting from the two fracture treatment are almost similar causing the overlap of green & purple events from the top (length & width view) & also shows the fracture height.

image-wrap.label: Figure 05
image-wrap.caption: (b) Fracture treatement surface pressure response in BH-08 (on left) & BH-10 (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: (b) Fracture treatement surface pressure response in BH-08 (on left) & BH-10 (right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 06 contains the fall off analysis for the injections in BH-08 ad BH-09. The interpretations indicate that the closure gradient for BH-09 (0.58 psi/ft) is significantly lower than the 0.62 psi/ft gradient estimated for BH-08. This confirmed the microseismic observations that BH-09 is not serving as a barrier for the fracture containment. The general understanding of non-pay sections to act as stress barriers for fracture height containment is ruled out for fracturing key upper BH units i.e BH-10 & BH-08.

image-wrap.label: Figure 06
image-wrap.caption: G-Function plot to compare closure pressure obtained from DFITs conducted in BH-08 & BH-09.

formatted-caption.caption-text: G-Function plot to compare closure pressure obtained from DFITs conducted in BH-08 & BH-09.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 07 (from El Rabaa et al) illustrates the fracture alignment to expect for a given well orientation with respect to the minimum & maximum horizontal stress. It predicts that a wellbore that is not properly aligned with the horizontal stresses will result in fractures that are misaligned with the wellbore. These misaligned fractures could result problems executing the fracture treatments and/or well performance issues.

image-wrap.label: Figure 07
image-wrap.caption: Figure from El. Rabaa, this depicts observed results from many laboratory tests on creating fractures from horizontal wellbores at different angles to the horizontal stresses along with very short or longer intervals of perforations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Figure from El. Rabaa, this depicts observed results from many laboratory tests on creating fractures from horizontal wellbores at different angles to the horizontal stresses along with very short or longer intervals of perforations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Due to operational contraints coiled tubing (CT) enabled sand jet perforating was employed in the cased and perfed well. CT hydrajetting created three holes at 120 deg phased holes at each jetting location. In general, 03-04 jetting locations were used for each stage resulting in a total of 9 perforations. Based on the work done by Smith and Larry (see Figure 08), the breakdown pressure for a longitudinal fracture should be about ¾ of the breakdown pressure for a transverse fracture for the given stress state.

image-wrap.label: Figure 08
image-wrap.caption: Figure reproduced from original figure in Smith.M.B et.al, Wellbore Breakdown Pressures for Strike-slip stress state

formatted-caption.caption-text: Figure reproduced from original figure in Smith.M.B et.al, Wellbore Breakdown Pressures for Strike-slip stress state

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to verify the fracture orientation and length, microseismic monitoring was conducted for the first three stages in the MBH-H (longitudinal fractured well). Microseismic events indicate that the fracture aligned mainly along the wellbore with an average fracture tip-to-tip length of 170 m. The fracture height was about 95 m as shown in Figure 09. These fracture lengths were found to be about 20-25m longer than average fracture half lengths observed in case of transverse well microseismic results.

image-wrap.label: Figure 09
image-wrap.caption: Main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on first three stages of a longitudinally fractured horizontal well: MBH-H

formatted-caption.caption-text: Main frac map view (length and width) & transverse view (height and width) of the HFM events on first three stages of a longitudinally fractured horizontal well: MBH-H

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 contains the surface injection pressures for two transversely fractured wells using different completion strategies (OH and Plug and Perf).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Surface pressure of fracture treatments conducted in Cased (MBH-C) & OH (MBH-F) Transverse horizontal wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surface pressure of fracture treatments conducted in Cased (MBH-C) & OH (MBH-F) Transverse horizontal wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: The relatively low surface pressure difference compared for the two completions of transverse fractures may be due to MBH-F being an OH ball drop completion, reducing the potential complexity/fracture tortuosity expected for a cased and cemented fracture completion. Figure 11 contains the surface pressure for the cased hole longitunal fractures. Note that these treatment pressures are further lower (300 to 400 psi) than the open hole tranverse fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Surface pressure of fracture treatments conducted in Cased Longitudinal Horizontal wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surface pressure of fracture treatments conducted in Cased Longitudinal Horizontal wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12(A) depicts the relative differences in cumulative production due to lower or higher Cfd for longitudinal and transverse fractures based on the work done by Soliman et. al. They also predicted that a longitudinal fracture should clean up easier than a transverse fracture given the difference between the nature of flow regimes in both fracture types. This paramerter was considered after low intial fracture fluid recovery was observed from transverse wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: From Soliman et.al, (a) Relative differences in cumulative production due to lower or higher Fcd for longitudinal & transverse fractures (b Comparisons between the productivity index of a transverse fracture (JhT) and longitudinally fractured horizontal well (single large fracture-along the wellbore) (JhL) as functions of the hydraulic fracture half-length/reservoir thickness ratio (xf/h) and dimensionless fracture conductivity (Fcd)

formatted-caption.caption-text: From Soliman et.al, (a) Relative differences in cumulative production due to lower or higher Fcd for longitudinal & transverse fractures (b Comparisons between the productivity index of a transverse fracture (JhT) and longitudinally fractured horizontal well (single large fracture-along the wellbore) (JhL) as functions of the hydraulic fracture half-length/reservoir thickness ratio (xf/h) and dimensionless fracture conductivity (Fcd)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Relative differences in cumulative production due to lower or higher Fcd for longitudinal & transverse fractures

Comparisons between the productivity index of a transverse fracture (JhT) and longitudinally fractured horizontal well (single large fracture-along the wellbore) (JhL) as functions of the hydraulic fracture half-length/reservoir thickness ratio (xf/h) and dimensionless fracture conductivity (Fcd)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fracture pressure history matching was conducted for each fracture stage. Figure 13 shows an example pressure match conducted on stage 04 with its matched fracture dimensions. Table 02 lists stagewise & average perf-to-perf half-lengths & fracture conductivities for these pressure history matches. The average fracture conductivity is 1500 md-ft. This results in an average Dimensionless Fracture Conductivity (Fcd) of 5.6 for a reservoir permeability of 1.5 md and the average adjacent stage perforation-to-perforation halflength of 67 m.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Example Pressure Match Result on Stage-04 of MBH-H

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example Pressure Match Result on Stage-04 of MBH-H

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 contains the measured PI’s for both the the longitudinal and tranversly fractured wells. Based on these actual measurements, the transverse well’s PI was about 1.43 times the PI of the longitudinal. This was about 15% lower than expected for the 07 producing fractures. This difference is likely due to the fact that the Soliman type curve assumes similar fracture conductivities for both the transverse and the longitudinal wells.

Two longitudinal horizontal wells and two transverse horizontal wells have been tested during appraisal phase of Mangala Barmer Hill. The bar plots in Figure 15(a) & (b) below represent cumulative production over time for each fractured well type in two different BH units ie. BH-10 & BH-06 respectively. The results indicate similar performance for both types of wells with the limited period production data as available during appraisal phase.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: (a) Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH10 (b) Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH6

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH10 (b) Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH6

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH10
Cumulative Production for each fracture well type in BH6

linkTarget.anchoringText: Transverse well fractures have a halflength of 164ft and 1000 mD-ft conductivity while longitudinal well fractures have a half-length of 250 ft and 1000 mD-ft conductivity. It is observed as per figure 16 that under depletion horizontal transverse well producer has marginally better production rates compared to horizontal longitudinal producer. At the end of 15 years of production forecast, transverse producer well recovers ~7% more oil compared to longitudinal producer well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Result of Mechanistic model run to compare Transverse Vs Longitudinal Cumulative Oil Produced over 15 years

formatted-caption.caption-text: Result of Mechanistic model run to compare Transverse Vs Longitudinal Cumulative Oil Produced over 15 years

linkTarget.anchoringText: For any secondary recovery mechanisms e.g. water-flood, longitudinal wells may be preferred so as to get better flood-front movement and sweep (Pearson et.al.). With a transverse producer well, risk for early water breakthrough may be higher. A pilot test as per Figure 17 is presently being planned to evaluate incremental benefits of water-flooding in Mangala Barmer Hill with a combination of longitudinal and transverse producer well. These results will be analyzed to strategize the field development concept.
